Because when you do that, it's almost like a little tiny pinhole you have in a balloon.

And those issues are, you know, the seemly, never-ending black on black homicide rate.
Why do we keep killing ourselves?
And number two, our dice(ph).
Why do we to continue to choose to eat what we eat?

With all due respect to Duane, I think, if you're a black person of - who've been fortunate enough to achieve some success, you do have an amount of response - a certain amount of responsibility to reach back to other people in your community.

You do have a responsible - a certain amount of responsibility to hold yourself up as a role model and to be actively involved in your community and with the people whom raised you or who you came up around.
I don't think it's enough to say, well, Minister Farrakhan is blaming white people for the problems in this country or the problems that we as African-Americans have.
Of course, we can't blame, you know, blame whitey for all of our problems.
Obviously, we have to do some things on our own.
We have to be self-sufficient.
And we have to work harder as a people.
But at the same time, those who have achieved have a responsibility to reach back and to push those who are downtrodden or try to help those who are downtrodden.
And so, I guess, to answer - where I come of on this is that I agree with Minister Farrakhan that we are losing our numbers.
It's a crisis.
There's no doubt about it.
